facts.text: Central Government requisitioned properties belonging to Hanskumar Kishanchand on February 19, 1941 under s.75A of Rules under Defence of India Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power companyferred by s. 75 A of the Rules framed under the Act, the Central Government requisitioned on February 19, 1941, certain properties belonging to Hanskumar Kishanchand, the appellant in Civil-Appeal No. 224 of 1954.

facts.text: No agreement on compensation amount, referred to Mr. Jafry, Additional District Judge, Khandwa under s.19(1)(b) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As there was numberagreement on the amount of companypensation payable to him, the Central Government referred the determination thereof to Mr. Jafry, Additional District Judge, Khandwa, under s. 19 1 b of the Act.

facts.text: Mr. Jafry awarded Rs. 13,000 as annual rent on March 31, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1943, Mr. Jafry pronounced his award, by which lie awarded a. sum of Rs. 13,000 as annual rent -for, the occupation of the premises.

facts.text: Appellant applied for leave to appeal to Federal Court under ss.109 and 110 CPC against amounts disallowed.

facts.text: Leave granted and certificate issued on August 25, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. August 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-Both these appeals are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Nagpur passed in an appeal under s. 19 1 f of the Defence of India Act, 1939,

facts.text: Both appeals dismissed as incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we dismiss both the appeals as incompetent.

issues.text: Whether the judgment of the High Court passed in appeal under s.19(1)(f) of the Defence of India Act, 1939, is an award and not a judgment, decree or order within the meaning of ss.109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure, rendering the appeal to the Supreme Court incompetent?

anchor.surface_text: At the opening of the hearing, a preliminary objection was taken by the learned Solicitor-General to the maintainability of Civil Appeal No. 224 of 1954 on the ground that the judgment of the High Court passed in appeal under s. 19 1   f  was an award and number a judgment, decree or order within the meaning of ss. 109 and I 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure, and that accordingly the appeal was incompetent.

issues.text: Whether the proceedings before the High Court under s.19(1)(f) constitute a civil proceeding in the ordinary jurisdiction of the Court, making its decision appealable under ss.109 and 110 CPC or Cl.29 of the Letters Patent?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Achbru Ram, learned counsel for the appellant does not dispute that the proceedings under s. 19 1   b  are by way of arbitration, but he contends that when once the matter comes before the High Court by way of appeal under s. 19 1  f , it becomes a civil proceeding under the ordinary jurisdiction of the Court, and that any decision therein is open to appeal under ss. 109 and I 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure. He further contends that even apart from those provisions, the appeal was competent under Cl. 29 of the Letters Patent, and that,

issues.text: Whether an appeal to the High Court under s.19(1)(f) of the Defence of India Act comes before it as a Court in its ordinary civil jurisdiction or as an arbitrator/persona designata?

anchor.surface_text: The principles being thus well-settled, we have to see in the present case whether an appeal to the High Court under s. 19 1  f  of the Act comes before it as a Court or as arbitrator. Under s. 19 1  b , the reference is admittedly to an arbitrator. He need not even be a Judge of a Court. It is sufficient that he is qualified to be appointed a Judge of the High Court.

issues.text: Whether, even if no appeal lies under ss.109/110 CPC or Letters Patent Cl.29, the Supreme Court has jurisdiction to grant special leave to appeal against the High Court's decision in appeal under s.19(1)(f)?

arguments.court_reasoning: Decision not a judgment/decree/order under Cl.29 Letters Patent.

arguments.claim: Arbitration agreement ousts ordinary courts; award replaces court adjudication; not appealable under general law like CPC ss.96 etc.

anchor.surface_text: Before discussing the authorities cited on either side in support of their respective contentions, it will be useful to state the wellestablished principles applicable to the determination of the present question. When parties enter into an agreement to have their dispute settled by arbitration, its effect is to take the lis out of the hands of the ordinary Courts of the land and to entrust it to the decision of what has been termed a private tribunal.

arguments.claim: Distinction between court decision in ordinary jurisdiction (appealable) and as persona designata in arbitration (award, not appealable).

anchor.surface_text: There is thus a sharp distinction between a decision which is pronounced by a Court in a cause which it hears on the merits, and one which is given by it in a proceeding for the filing of an award. The former is a judgment, decree or order rendered in the exercise of its normal jurisdiction as a Civil Court, and that is appealable under the general law as for example, under ss. 96, 100, 104, 109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

arguments.claim: Statutory arbitration same as consensual; s.46 Arbitration Act applies; reference to court as persona designata yields award not appealable.

anchor.surface_text: The position in law is the same when the reference to arbitration is made not under agreement of parties but under provisions of a statute. The result of those provisions again is to withdraw the dispute from the jurisdiction of the ordinary courts and to refer it for the decision of a private tribunal.

arguments.claim: Precedents like Rangoon Botatoung, Salsette Building Sites etc. support that such decisions are not judgments appealable under CPC or Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Government, the decisions in Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon 1 , The Special Officer, Salsette Building Sites v. Dossabhai Bezonji 2 , The Special Officer, Salsette Building Sites v. Dassabhai Bozanji Moti.wala 3 , Manavikraman Tirumalpad v. The Collector of the Nilgris 4  and Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Limited 5  were relied on as supporting the contention that the present appeals are incompetent.

arguments.claim: National Telephone distinguished: there reference to established court imports ordinary procedure and appeal rights; here explicit arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: Now, Mr. Achhru Ram contests this last proposition, and relies strongly on the decision in National Telephone Company Limited v. Postmaster-General 4 , as supporting his position. ... There is thus nothing in National Telephone Company Limited v. Postmaster-General 1 , which can be said to conflict with the law as laid down in Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon. 2  that when the reference is to a Court as arbitrator, its decision is not open to appeal.

arguments.claim: Chelikani Rama Rao: confirms distinction between court as court vs arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between the two classes of cases, where the reference is to court as court and where the reference is to it as arbitrator, was again pointed out by the Privy Council in Secretary of State for India v. Chelikani Rama Rao 3 .

arguments.claim: Under s.19(1)(b) reference to arbitrator (not necessarily judge); s.19(1)(f) appeal to High Court as designated authority not court; continues arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: The principles being thus well-settled, we have to see in the present case whether an appeal to the High Court under s. 19 1  f  of the Act comes before it as a Court or as arbitrator. Under s. 19 1  b , the reference is admittedly to an arbitrator. He need not even be a Judge of a Court.

arguments.claim: Appeal under s.19(1)(f) expressly against 'award'; appeal continues original arbitration proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that, in the present case, the reference was to a District Judge would not affect the position. Then again, the decision of the arbitrator appointed under s. 19 1  b  is expressly referred to in s. 19 1  f  as an award. Now, an appeal is essentially a continuation of the original proceedings,

arguments.claim: s.19(1)(g) excludes application of other laws to arbitrations under s.19.

anchor.surface_text: Then we have sub-s. g , which is as follows Save as provided in this section and in any rules made thereunder, nothing in any law for the time being in force shall apply to arbitrations under this section.

arguments.claim: Kollegal Silk Filatures: appeal under s.19(1)(f) is arbitration proceeding; High Court acts as arbitration tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether an appeal under s. 19 1  f  is of the nature of arbitration proceedings, and whether the decision given therein is an award came up directly for consideration in Kollegal Silk Filatures Ltd. v. Province of Madras 1  before a Bench of the Madras High Court consisting of Patanjali Sastri and Chandrasekhara Aiyar JJ.

arguments.claim: High Court decision under s.19(1)(f) not judgment/decree/order under ss.109/110 CPC or Cl.29 Letters Patent; appeals incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore hold that the decision of the High Court in the appeal under that provision is not a judgment, decree or order either within ss. 109 and I 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure or cl. 29 of the Letters Patent of the Nagpur High Court, which corresponds to cl. 39 of the Letters Patent

arguments.claim: Even if no appeal under 109/110 or Cl.29, Supreme Court can grant special leave as successor to Privy Council/Federal Court power.
arguments.court_reasoning: Power under s.3(a)(ii) Federal Court Act only against 'judgment' i.e. J/D/O; here it's award.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we dismiss both the appeals as incompetent.

holdings.text: The decision of the High Court in the appeal under s.19(1)(f) of the Defence of India Act is not a judgment, decree or order either within ss.109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure or cl.29 of the Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore hold that the decision of the High Court in the appeal under that provision is number a judgment, decree or order either within ss. 109 and I 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure or cl. 29 of the Letters Patent of the Nagpur High Court, which corresponds to cl. 39 of the Letters Patent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceedings under s.19(1)(b) and appeal under s.19(1)(f) are arbitration; High Court acts as persona designata; appeal continues arbitration; s.19(1)(g) excludes other laws; precedents like Rangoon Botatoung, Kollegal Silk Filatures followed.

holdings.text: The reference under s.19(1)(b) and the appeal under s.19(1)(f) are arbitration proceedings; the decision of the High Court in the appeal is an award.

anchor.surface_text: On these provisions, the contention on behalf of the Government is that the reference under s. 19 1 , b  and the appeal under s. 19 1   f  are all arbitration proceedings, that the decision of the High Court in the appeal is really an award,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19(1)(b) appoints arbitrator qualified for HC judge, not necessarily judge; s.19(1)(f) appeal against 'award'; continuation of arbitration; High Court as designated authority; s.19(1)(g) bars other laws.

holdings.text: The appeal under s.19(1)(f) to the High Court is before it as an arbitrator/persona designata, not as a Court in ordinary civil jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The principles being thus well-settled, we have to see in the present case whether an appeal to the High Court under s. 19 1  f  of the Act comes before it as a Court or as arbitrator. Under s. 19 1  b , the reference is admittedly to an arbitrator.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrator under s.19(1)(b) need not be judge; appeal to HC as designated; precedents distinguish court as court vs persona designata; National Telephone distinguished.

holdings.text: We agree that the appeal under s.19(1)(f) is an arbitration proceeding and the High Court acts as an arbitration tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with this decision that the appeal under s. 19 1   f  is an arbitration proceeding. We must therefore hold that the decision of the High Court in the appeal under that provision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Kollegal Silk Filatures Ltd. v. Province of Madras; s.19(1)(g) covers entire proceedings from arbitrator to HC appeal.

holdings.text: No appeal lies to Supreme Court under ss.109/110 CPC or cl.29 Letters Patent against High Court decision under s.19(1)(f); present appeals incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: , which corresponds to cl. 39 of the Letters Patent of the Calcutta, Madras and Bombay High Courts, and that, therefore, the present appeals are incompetent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not J/D/O; arbitration award; precedents like Rangoon Botatoung, Salsette, etc.; ousts ordinary appeal rights.

holdings.text: Supreme Court/Federal Court has no power to grant special leave under s.3(a)(ii) Federal Court Enlargement Act against High Court decision under s.19(1)(f) as it is not a judgment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Special leave only against judgment/decree/order; here award, not J/D/O.

holdings.text: Both appeals are dismissed as incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we dismiss both the appeals as incompetent.

holdings.text: An arbitration reference withdraws dispute from ordinary courts; decision is award final unless set aside; distinction between court as court (appealable) and persona designata (award, not appealable).

anchor.surface_text: Before discussing the authorities cited on either side in support of their respective contentions, it will be useful to state the wellestablished principles applicable to the determination of the present question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of general principles from precedents; applied to facts.

precedents.case_name: Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon
precedents.cited_proposition: Decision of court in arbitration proceedings under Land Acquisition Act is an award, not a judgment, decree or order appealable under ss. 109 and 110 CPC or to Privy Council.
precedents.cited_holding: Their Lordships cannot accept the argument or suggestion that when once the claimant is admitted to the High Court he has all the rights of an ordinary suitor, including the right to carry an award made in an arbitration as to the value of land taken for public purposes up to this Board as if it were a decree of the High Court made in the course of its ordinary jurisdiction.

The Collector of the Nilgris 4 and Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Limited 5 were relied on as supporting the companytention that the present appeals are incompetent. In Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon 1 , the facts were that certain properties had been acquired tinder the Land Aequistion Act of 1894

precedents.case_name: The Special Officer, Salsette Building Sites v. Dossabhai Bezonji
precedents.cited_proposition: Decision of High Court in appeal under s. 54 Land Acquisition Act is not a judgment within Cl. 39 Letters Patent appealable to Privy Council.
precedents.cited_holding: This passage shows that it is a mistake to suppose that the award made in such a case by the High Court is a decree within the ordinary jurisdiction to which the Civil Procedure Code refers and it seems to me it would be equally erroneous to regard such an award as a final judgment or order within the meaning of clause 39 of the Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Officer, Salsette Building Sites v. Dassabhai Bozanji Moti. wala 3 , Manavikraman Tirumalpad v. The Collector of the Nilgris 4 and Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Limited 5 were relied on as supporting the companytention that the present appeals are incompetent. In Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon 1 , the facts were that certain properties had been acquired under the Land Acquisition Act of 1894, and the Collector had determined the amount of companypensation payable to the quondam owners.

precedents.case_name: The Special Officer, Salsette Building Sites v. Dassabhai Bozanji Motiwala
precedents.cited_proposition: Privy Council accepted the interpretation that High Court award under Land Acquisition appeal is not appealable.

precedents.citation: Manavikraman Tirumalpad v. The Collector of the Nilgris 4

anchor.surface_text: Manavikraman Tirumalpad v. The Collector of the Nilgris 4 and Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Limited 5 were relied on as supporting the companytention that the present appeals are incompetent. In Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon 1 , the facts were that certain properties had been acquired under the Land Acquisition Act of 1894, and the Collector had determined the amount of companypensation payable to the quondam owners. On their objection as to the quantum of companypensation, the matter was referred to the decision of the Chief Court of Burma.

precedents.case_name: Manavikraman Tirumalpad v. The Collector of the Nilgris
precedents.cited_proposition: Judgment of High Court in appeal under Land Acquisition Act not a judgment within Cl. 15 Letters Patent for further appeal.

precedents.citation: Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Limited 5

anchor.surface_text: Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Limited 5 were relied on as supporting the companytention that the present appeals are incompetent. In Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon 1 , the facts were that certain properties had been acquired under the Land Acquisition Act of 1894, and the Collector had determined the amount of companypensation payable to the quondam owners. On their objection as to the quantum of companypensation, the matter was referred to the decision of the Chief Court of Burma. It was heard by a Bench of two Judges, who determined that a sum of Rs. 13,25,720 was payable as companypensation.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Limited
precedents.cited_proposition: Decision of High Court in appeal under Calcutta Improvement Act not appealable to Privy Council.
precedents.cited_holding: in view of the decision in Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon there could be no right of appeal against the decision of the High Court.

precedents.citation: National Telephone Company Limited v. Postmaster-General 4

anchor.surface_text: Now, Mr. Achhru Ram contests this last proposition, and relies strongly on the decision in National Telephone Company Limited v. Postmaster-General 4 , as supporting his position. There, the question arose on the construction of certain provisions of the Telegraph Arbitration Act, 1909.

precedents.case_name: National Telephone Company Limited v. Postmaster-General
precedents.cited_proposition: Reference to an established Court imports ordinary incidents of procedure and right of appeal.
precedents.cited_holding: When a question is stated to be referred to an established Court without more, it, in my opinion, imports that the ordinary incidents of the procedure of that Court are to attach, and also that any general right of appeal from its decision likewise attaches.

precedents.citation: Secretary of State for India v. Chelikani Rama Rao 3

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between the two classes of cases, where the reference is to court as court and where the reference is to it as arbitrator, was again pointed out by the Privy Council in Secretary of State for India v. Chelikani Rama Rao 3 . There, the question arose with reference to certain provisions of the Madras Forest Act, 1882.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State for India v. Chelikani Rama Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between reference to court as court vs as arbitrator; under Forest Act, it's as court.
precedents.cited_holding: the proceedings under the Forest Act were essentially different in character. The claim was the assertion of a legal right to possession of and property in land and if the ordinary Courts of the country are seized of a dispute of that character, it would require [...] a specific limitation to exclude the ordinary incidents of litigation.

precedents.citation: Kollegal Silk Filatures Ltd. v. Province of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: The question whether an appeal under s. 19 (1) (f) is of the nature of arbitration proceedings, and whether the decision given therein is an award came up directly for consideration in Kollegal Silk Filatures Ltd. v. Province of Madras 1 before a Bench of the Madras High Court consisting of Patanjali Sastri and Chandrasekhara Aiyar JJ.

precedents.case_name: Kollegal Silk Filatures Ltd. v. Province of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Appeal under s. 19(1)(f) Defence of India Act is arbitration proceeding; High Court acts as arbitration tribunal.
precedents.cited_holding: the word arbitration in s. 19(1)(g) of the Act covered the entire proceedings from their commencement before the arbitrator to their termination in the High Court on appeal where an appeal had been preferred, and the High Court in hearing and deciding the appeal acted essentially as an arbitration tribunal.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

In the result, we dismiss both the appeals as incompetent.
